thread.title: Punt return seals the deal in Oscar Smith's comeback
thread.title_full: Punt return seals the deal in Oscar Smith's comeback | HamptonRoads.com | PilotOnline.com

author: Lee Tolliver
title: Punt return seals the deal in Oscar Smith's comeback
text:
CHESAPEAKE During halftime, with his Oscar Smith football team sitting in a very strange position of being behind, DeAngelo White pulled his special teams coach aside and spoke his mind.
"He told me that if the next punt was short or wobbly that he was going to go for it," Terrance Duke said. "I told him not to tell me but to show me."
He showed him all right.
White capped one of South Hampton Roads' most remarkable comebacks when he fielded an Indian River punt at the Oscar Smith 41-yard line in the final minute and raced down the left sideline before diving into a pile of defenders at the end zone line to help rally the Tigers to a 15-14 victory over Indian River in front of a packed house at Hickory High School. It was Oscar Smith's 79th consecutive victory over a Southeastern District opponent.
On the opposite side of the field, Oscar Smith's bench went ballistic - dancing and cheering for all they were worth.
"I saw it coming short and just took it," White said. "I just couldn't believe it. Oh my God. We just never gave up and it was so open down the line."
It wasn't final until Cameron Lester's extra point, but with 24.7 seconds left, it was hard not to go crazy.
The Braves had all but smothered Oscar Smith for the entire game. That left the matter to the Tigers' special teams, which were able to make things interesting and victorious at the end.
Oscar Smith scored the game's first two points when Jahmeek Jones blocked a Braves' punt for a safety. But Indian River scored the game's next 14 points to take command.
Oscar Smith's comeback started when the snap for an Indian River punt sailed over the head of punter Jalen Williams, setting up a Tigers touchdown.
"There are three phases in a game... 48 minutes, not three quarters," Duke said. "He fielded that punt in full stride and hit it like he told me he would.
"That's manning up and never giving up."
Lee Tolliver, 757-222-5844,
lee.tolliver@pilotonline.com
Twitter: @LeeTolliver
